RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
SOUTHSIDE WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT

Executive Summary

The following information is a summary of the Risk Management of chlorine and sulfur dioxide in use at the Southside Wastewater Treatment Plant.  This plan is intended to prevent and minimize the impacts of accidental releases of extremely hazardous substances.  The chlorine and sulfur dioxide inventories exceed the threshold quantities established in the Risk Management Plan Program (RMP) requirements.

The Southside Wastewater Treatment Plant uses chlorine and sulfur dioxide for chlorination and de-chlorination (disinfection) respectfully, of plant effluent.  The use of these chemicals is subject to the provisions of the RMP requirements, due to their "above-threshold" quantities.

Five-Year Accident History
On June 13, 2005 at approximately 9am, the maintenance department responded to an alarm from the safety detection system in the chlorine evaporator room.  In the course of finding the leak, it was determined that a valve did not isolate the system and a small quantity of residual chlorine in the piping was released when testing the system.  The system was worked on for 5.5 hours an

d only a trace amount of chlorine was released.  One maintenance person working on the system did experience some nauseousness with the release.  He has experienced no problems since.  The leak was contained in the evaporator room and no offsite impacts occurred.    No offsite responders were notified because of the small quantity released.  It was determined that a block assembly that was previously added was bad when installed.  There were no process changes resulting from this incident.  Personnel were counseled on the proper use of SCBAs and the leaking parts were replaced.  


The Emergency Response Plan
The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that the Southside Wastewater Treatment Plant maintains up-to-date and complete written emergency action plans (EAPs) and effective response capabilities for all covered processes.  Comprehensive emergency action plans, when combined with emergency response training and drills, can effectively minimize the impact of an accidental release by ensuring proper and quick facility response.  A summary of the requirements as outline in this section is as follows:

* This facility shall investigate each incident that resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release.
* This investigation shall be initiated promptly, no later than 48 hours following the incident.
* The guidelines and reports included herein shall be followed for each incident.
* All affected personnel whose job tasks are affected by the findings shall review the findings.
* Investigation summaries shall be retained for five years.
